In this unit, we explored how sampling can help collect, analyze, and interpret a set of data to address statistical questions. At the end of this Investigation, ask yourself:

What do you know about the statistical problem-solving process?

In a statistical investigation, we begin with statistical questions. Then we collect data, analyze data, and interpret data to answer questions.

Sometimes, it is too difficult or impossible to collect data from a whole population. It may take too much time or money or impossible to contact or reach each participant in the population. So we can use samples to make predictions about a whole population.

It is important that samples represent the population. Random sampling is giving every member of a population an equally likely chance of being selected. Random sampling procedures help us to collect representative samples.
